content:
• Monday, November 9, 2015
  • TTGT

    TechTarget grows revenues, beats on profit with 54% increase

    • TechTarget (TTGT -2.2%) logged a mixed Q3 report as revenues climbed nearly 10% but missed expectations slightly and adjusted net income rose more than 50%.
    • EBITDA climbed 40%, to $6.88M, beating an expected $6.65B.
    • Revenue breakout: Core Online, $20.6M (up 6%); IT Deal Alert, $6.4M (up 35%); Events, $1.9M (down 12%).
    • It's guiding for Q4 revenue of $30M-$31M (below an expected $35.2M) and EBITDA of $7.4M-$8.2M (light of an expected $10M). It sees dougle-digit revenue growth for 2016 in an early look, with EBITDA growth of about 25%.
    • Shares were flat in after-hours trading.
     
     
     
     
    | 7:21 PM
  • RAX

    Rackspace up 7.8% after earnings/guidance; buybacks, margin gains lift EPS

    • Rackspace (NYSE:RAX) spent $250M on buybacks in Q3. The company is three months removed from upping its buyback authorization to $1B, and promising to buy back at least $500M worth of shares in 6-9 months.
    • Adjusted EBITDA margin was 34.9%, up 180 bps Q/Q and 40 bps Y/Y, and above guidance of 33%-34%. Q4 guidance is still at 33%-34%. Adjusted free cash flow rose 9% Y/Y to $45.2M, with adjusted EBITDA growth offsetting a 9% increase in capex to $127.7M (a healthy 25% of revenue).
    • GAAP costs/expenses rose 8% to $452.4M. Average monthly revenue per server rose by $28 Q/Q and $39 Y/Y to $1,444. Servers deployed rose 2% Q/Q and 7% Y/Y to 118,654.
    • Rackspace's $350M debt offering consists of senior notes due 2024. A portion of the proceeds will be used to repay credit facility debt; the remainder will be used for general corporate purposes that may include buybacks. Rackspace ended Q3 with $213.5M in cash, and $25.1M in debt.
    • Shares have risen to $29.20 after hours, after dropping 4.2% in regular trading. BofA/Merrill's pre-earnings upgrade is looking good.
    • Q3 results/Q4 guidance, PR
     
     
     
     
    | 7:11 PM | 2 Comments
  • KEYW

    KEYW down 15.6% after Q3 miss, guidance cuts

    • KEYW Holding now expects 4%-6% 2015 revenue growth for its core Government Solutions segment; prior guidance was for 4%-8% growth. Revenue guidance for the Commercial segment (Hexis/HawkEye G) is now at $13M-$15M vs. a prior $15M; it was at $25M prior to the Q2 report.
    • Government Solutions is still expected to see a 12%-14% adjusted EBITDA margin. The adjusted EBITDA loss forecast for Commercial has been lowered to $30M-$32M from $30M-$34M.
    • Government Solutions revenue rose 2.9% Y/Y to $78.1M; Commercial revenue was roughly flat at $3M. GAAP operating expenses rose by $3.1M Y/Y to $28.3M. HawkEye G installations have risen to 36 from 30 from the time of the Q2 report, with revenue-generating customers rising to 18 from 16.
    • Shares have plunged to $6.24 after hours. The 52-week low is $5.60.
    • Q3 results, PR
     
     
     
     
    | 6:56 PM
  • SFXE

    SFX Entertainment bounds 13.9% after Q3 earnings swing to loss

    • SFX Entertainment (SFXE -8.3%) is up 13.9% after hours following a Q3 report where it swung to a net loss with revenues dipping and direct costs rising.
    • Revenue that fell 7% would have declined less than 1% in constant currency.
    • Live revenue (86.3% of total) was $114.9M in Q3; Platform revenue was $18.3M.
    • During the quarter, SFX held 286 festivals and events (31 defined as events, as festivals with single-day capacities of over 10,000 attendees); total attendance was up 24.8% to 1.946M.
    • Of note with the company's ongoing go-private saga is the company's liquidity: It had $295M principal outstanding on its 9.625% second-lien senior notes due 2019, and $30M drawn against a revolving credit facility. Cash and equivalents came to $59.8M.
     
     
     
     
    | 6:47 PM | 5 Comments
  • ROVI

    Rovi getting dropped from S&P 400, Penn Virginia from 600; PVA -8.5%

    • Genworth Financial (getting dropped from the S&P 500) is taking ROVI's spot in the S&P MidCap 400 following the Nov. 17 close. Rovi, in turn, will take Penn Virginia's (PVA) spot in the S&P SmallCap 600.
    • Penn Virginia has fallen to $0.75 after hours. Rovi hasn't yet moved.
     
     
     
     
    | 6:40 PM | 1 Comment
  • SNY

    Lawsuit accuses Sanofi of stalling MS drug to avoid $708M in payments

    • A lawsuit seeking at least $236M is charging Sanofi (SNY -2.5%) with delaying development on Lemtrada, its multiple sclerosis drug, in order to avoid $708M it would owe to rights holders tied to its deal to purchase Genzyme.
    • Development of Lemtrada was in process at Genzyme when Sanofi purchased the company, and the deal included tradable certificates worth money if Lemtrada was approved by March 31, 2014.
    • American Stock Transfer & Trust Co., a trustee for those rights holders, says Sanofi intentionally took a "slow path" to approval despite promising "diligent efforts" to meet the goals.
    • The trustee also charges that after November 2014 approval, Sanofi underfunded marketing for the drug and actively promoted another, meaning that sales benchmarks were missed.
     
     
     
     
    | 6:32 PM | 8 Comments
  • DLGNF

    Activist Elliott Management opposes Atmel-Dialog deal; ATML -4.7%

    • Elliott, which has waged many successful activist campaigns involving tech companies, argues Dialog Semi's (OTCPK:DLGNF) planned cash/stock purchase of Atmel (NASDAQ:ATML) is too costly, and will yield little in cost savings. The firm controls 2.9% of Dialog's voting rights.
    • Shareholder advisory firm ISS came out against the Atmel deal in late October. Dialog's shares have fallen sharply since the deal was announced in September, thanks partly to Dialog's weak Q3 report.
    • Atmel has fallen to $7.30 after hours. Shares are now only $0.03 above where they traded prior to the deal announcement. Dialog shareholders vote on the deal on Nov. 19.
     
     
     
     
    | 6:20 PM | 2 Comments
  • APPS

    Digital Turbine revenues rise 11% sequentially but miss consensus

    • Digital Turbine (APPS -1.9%) logged fiscal Q2 results where revenue more than tripled Y/Y -- thanks to the spring acquisition of Appia -- but missed expectations.
    • Revenues rose 11% sequentially to $20.7M, with constant-dollar growth spread across all segments. Adjusted gross profit was $4.6M (up sequentially from $4.5M), with a 22% margin (down from Q1's 24%).
    • In Advertising, DT Media revenue was up 27% and Appia Core revenue up 14%. In DT Marketplace, DT Content and DT Pay revenue increased 6% in constant currency.
    • CEO Bill Stone says the company expects to achieve its revenue-per-device target of $2 this year.
    • Shares were flat in postmarket action.
     
     
     
     
    | 6:15 PM | 1 Comment
  • GPS

    Gap -5.2% after Banana Republic sales crumble

    • Gap (NYSE:GPS) reports total sales for October fell 4.8% to $1.20B (flat in constant currency). Comp sales were down 3% during the month.
    • Comparable sales growth by brand: Gap Global -4%, Banana Republic Global -15%, Old Navy Global +2%.
    • The company expects Adj. EPS (excl. strategic actions) in Q3 to be in the range of $0.62-$0.63.
    • GPS -5.2% after hours to $26.25.
     
     
     
     
    | 6:06 PM | 3 Comments
  • TRTN

    TAL, Triton to combine in world's biggest intermodeal freight container lessor

    • TAL International (TAL -3.1%) and privately held Triton Container International Limited are combining in an all-stock merger to build the world's largest lessor of intermodal freight containers.
    • TAL shares are down 1.8% after hours.
    • The combination will boast a combined fleet of almost 5M 20-foot-equivalent containers (TEUs) and revenue earning assets of $8.7B, the companies say.
    • The two expect $40M in annual SG&A synergies, fully implemented by the end of 2016.
    • Plans for are Triton shareholders to own 55% of equity to TAL shareholders' 45%. The merger will be executed under a new holding company, Triton International, domiciled in Bermuda with an NYSE listing planned.
    • TAL shareholders will get one share of the new company along with a special dividend of $0.54/share on closing.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:59 PM | 8 Comments
  • AVG

    AVG launches 1.67M-share buyback; shares +3.4%

    • AVG plans to repurchase up to 1.67M shares (~3% of outstanding shares) through May 10, 2016 to offset its restricted stock unit and stock option grant obligations.
    • The moves comes less than a week after AVG tumbled due to a Q3 miss and soft Q4 guidance. Shares have risen to $19.84 after hours.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:59 PM | 1 Comment
  • ANGI

    Angie's List closes up 5.4% after activist wanting HomeAdvisor merger ups stake

    • In its latest13D filing, TCS Capital discloses it now owns a 6.2M-share (10.7%) stake in Angie's List (NASDAQ:ANGI), up from a prior 9.1%.
    • TCS has been critical of Angie's management, and argued chairman John Huang's interests aren't aligned with those of unaffiliated shareholders. The firm has also pushed for a merger with InterActiveCorp-owned (IACI) HomeAdvisor, arguing it would yield major cost savings and end a fierce marketing battle between the companies.
    • Shares rose to $7.99 in regular trading, and made a new 52-week high of $8.17. They're still well below a July 2013 high of $28.32.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:50 PM | 2 Comments
  • SYF

    Synchrony replacing Genworth in S&P 500; SYF higher, GNW lower

    • Synchrony Financial (NYSE:SYF) will replace former GE unit Genworth Financial (NYSE:GNW) in the S&P 500 on Nov. 17. GE is set to fully spin off its Synchrony stake through a share exchange.
    • SYF +1.3% after hours. GNW -1.3%.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:40 PM | 1 Comment

  • After Hours Gainers / Losers

    • Top gainers, as of 5.25 p.m.: SCLN +25.3%. MDR +16.1%. BLCM +12.4%. OVAS-OLD +10.5%. NVRO +10.1%.
    • Top losers, as of 5.25p.m.: XONE -20.3%. SGMS -20.0%. TXTR -15.0%. ECR -10.5%. OSTK -9.7%.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:40 PM | 1 Comment
  • NCMI

    National CineMedia +1.9% after boosting guidance for Q4, 2015

    • In-theater marketing firm National CineMedia (NCMI -1.8%) is up 1.9% after hours, mitigating today's decline, after boosting guidance for Q4 and 2015 amid Q3 results where it missed expectations slightly.
    • Adjusted OIBDA rose 14.2% to $59.6M, above an expected $58.6M.
    • For Q4, the company raised guidance on revenues (up 2% to 6% to $125M-$131M, above an expected $122.7M) and OIBDA to $68M-$74M, above consensus of $67.7M.
    • For full 2015, it sees revenues up 10%-12% (to total of $435M-$441M, above expected $433.4M) and OIBDA of $223M-$229M (vs. $222M expected).
     
     
     
     
    | 5:33 PM
  • OUT

    Clear Channel mulling billboard asset sale that could draw $800M

    • Clear Channel Outdoor Holdings (CCO -4.8%) is looking at the sale of U.S. billboard assets that might collectively come to $800M, Reuters reports.
    • The company has hired Moelis & Co. to advise it on a sale, sources said. The assets in question reportedly generate annual EBITDA of $60M-$70M.
    • Buyers could include rivals like Outfront Media (NYSE:OUT), Lamar Advertising (NASDAQ:LAMR), GTCR and JCDecaux. Clear Channel could divest holdings in a variety of regions, which could include Las Vegas, Seattle, Portland, and Bentonville and Fort Smith, Ark.
    • About 88% of Clear Channel Outdoor is held by iHeartMedia (IHRT -10%).
     
     
     
     
    | 5:22 PM
  • SGMS

    Scientific Games -20.1% after revenue miss; lottery sales under pressure

    • Scientific Games' (NASDAQ:SGMS) Lottery revenue fell 10.1% Y/Y to $191.3M. Within the segment, services revenue fell 6.6% to $45M, product sales fell 74.2% to $8.7M, and instant games rose 5.2% to $137.6M. The product decline is blamed on "lower hardware sales to international customers reflecting a lower level of demand and international lottery bid activity."
    • Due to the Bally merger, Gaming revenue rose 161% to $429.1M. However, non-Bally revenue fell by $22M. Total gaming machine unit sales fell Y/Y relative to combined year-ago Scientific/Bally sales. Gaming services revenue totaled $244.3M, and product revenue $184.8M.
    • Official EPS of -$7.88 included $7.03 worth of goodwill impairment, asset impairment, and other charges. Op. cash flow rose to $141.1M from $126.3M a year ago, while free cash flow fell to $50.3M from $64.7M due to a 71% increase in capex to $90.8M.
    • Shares have tumbled to $9.25 after hours.
    • Q3 results, PR
     
     
     
     
    | 5:21 PM | 1 Comment
  • CPE

    Callon Petroleum buys interests in Midland fields, to launch 10M-share offering

    • Callon Petroleum (NYSE:CPE) -6% AH after announcing a public offering of 10M common shares, with an underwriters option to purchase up to an additional 1.5M units.
    • CPE says it plans to use the proceeds to be used to repay amounts outstanding under its credit facility, which have been used in part to finance acquisitions - such as today's $29.5M acquisition of additional working interests in the Carpe Diem and Casselman-Bohannon fields in the Midland Basin - with any remainder being used for general corporate purposes, which may include future acquisitions.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:15 PM
  • QNST

    QuinStreet posts fiscal Q1 miss though loss narrows, revenues grow

    • Online marketing firm QuinStreet (QNST -5.3%) marked fiscal Q1 results where net loss narrowed slightly, but still lagged expectations, and the company missed top-line consensus as well.
    • Revenues grew, though, and CEO Doug Valenti said "We continued to see strong growth from the new product, market and media initiatives that are revitalizing our business and that are representing an ever-larger share of our mix." The company reiterated its outlook for about 10% revenue growth in 2016.
    • Operating cash flow was $3.2M; QuinStreet closed its Q1 with $61M in cash, $46M in net cash.
    • Shares were flat in after-hours trading.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:13 PM
  • XONE

    ExOne down 20.9% after Q3 miss, major revenue guidance cut

    • Following its major Q3 miss, ExOne (NASDAQ:XONE) expects full-year revenue of $40M, down from $43.9M a year and well below prior guidance of $58M-$60M. Consensus had already fallen to $55.1M. Gross margin guidance has been cut to 17%-21% from 30%-34%.
    • The 3D printer maker blames its top-line pressures on lengthy sales cycles for production machines (said to range from 30 days to 15 months), and says it's seeing "increasing difficulties in our ability to forecast the time cycle from order placement to customer acceptance." Chinese and Russian forex pressures are also blamed. 3D printing peers have also been having a rough time.
    • Printer sales: 5 printers were sold in Q3, down from 7 in Q2 and 8 a year ago. 1 high-end S-Max printer was sold, compared with none in Q2 and 1 a year ago. 3 Innovent machines (smaller, R&D-focused) were sold vs. 5 in Q2 and none a year ago.
    • Financials: Gross margin was 13.2% vs. 13% in Q2 and 25.8% a year ago. Lower sales, mix changes, and higher production costs are blamed for the Y/Y drop. R&D spend fell 19% Y/Y to a mere $1.8M; SG&A spend rose 9% to $5M. ExOne ended Q3 with $20.3M in cash (down $4.5M Q/Q), and $2M in debt.
    • Shares have plunged to $8.25 after hours.
    • Q3 results, PR
     
     
     
     
    | 5:02 PM | 7 Comments
  • PFSW

    PFSweb EPS of $0.08

    • PFSweb (NASDAQ:PFSW): Q3 EPS of $0.08 may not be comparable to consensus of -$0.09.
    • Revenue of $71.18M (+24.7% Y/Y) beats by $6.96M.
    • Shares +6.93% AH.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:00 PM
  • CALL

    MagicJack VocalTec up 7% on Q3 profit, raised 2015 guidance

    • MagicJack VocalTec (NASDAQ:CALL) is up 7% after hours in the wake of Q3 results featured a solid beat on profits and lower churn though revenue dipped slightly.
    • Revenue breakout: Access rights renewal, $16.2M (64% of total); device sales, $4.5M; prepaid minutes, $2M; access and wholesale charges, $1.6M; other, $1.1M.
    • The company reported 2.53M active magicJack subscribers at quarter's end after activating 119K subs. Churn dropped to 2.7%.
    • Free cash flow was $5.7M; cash and equivalents were $79.6M at quarter's end, against no debt.
    • It's boosted full-year guidance on EBITDA to about $34M, above expectations for $32.9M.
    • Conference call to come at 5 p.m. ET.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:51 PM | 2 Comments
  • JIVE

    Jive up 7.1% after Q3 beat, healthy guidance

    • JIVE Software has risen to $5.10 after hours after beating Q3 estimates and guiding for Q4 revenue of $49M-$50M and EPS of -$0.04 to -$0.06 vs. a consensus of $49.2M and -$0.08.
    • Billings: Short-term billings rose 6% Y/Y in Q3 to $47.9M, an improvement from Q2's 3% growth. Total billings fell 14% to $43.3M. Both short-term and total billings trailed revenue of $49.9M. Jive still expects 0%-5% 2015 short-term billings growth.
    • GAAP operating expenses fell by $1M Y/Y to $40.5M. Jive ended Q3 with $119.6M in cash (down $7.1M Q/Q), and $4.2M in debt. Full-year free cash flow is expected to be in a range of -$2M to -$7M.
    • Q3 results, PR
     
     
     
     
    | 4:46 PM
  • SPAN

    Span - America Medical Systems reports FQ4 results

    • Span - America Medical Systems (NASDAQ:SPAN): FQ4 EPS of $0.43
    • Revenue of $17.7M (+36.2% Y/Y)
    • Shares +1.33%.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:40 PM
  • TUBE

    TubeMogul jumps 9.6% after solid Q3 beats all around, raised guidance

    • TubeMogul (TUBE -2.7%) is up 9.6% after hours following Q3 results that beat on top and bottom lines and featured a bump to full-year guidance.
    • Net loss widened to $3.8M but easily beat expectations; total spend of $103.4M was up 65% and revenues grew even stronger. Gross profit was up 63% to $31.1M.
    • Adjusted EBITDA came in positive at $0.8M, vs. expectations for a loss of $1.4M.
    • Revenue breakout: Platform direct, $17.9M (up 47.7%); Platform services, $28.6M (up 86.8%).
    • It's guiding to Q4 total spend of $126M-$128M, revenue of $51-$53M, and EBITDA of -$2M to break-even. TubeMogul raised full-year guidance, now seen at total spend of $406M-$408M, revenue of $173M-$175M (above an expected $166.2M), and EBITDA of -$3M to -$1M (higher than an expected -$5.9M).
    • Conference call to come at 5 p.m. ET.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:36 PM
  • ASRT

    Depomed Q3 top line up 104%; net income down 283%; guidance raised; shares up 5%

    • Depomed (DEPO) Q3 results ($M): Total Revenues: 104.9 (+103.7%); Nucynta: 64.9; Gralise: 21.1 (+29.4%); Cambia: 7.1 (+21.0%); Lazanda: 5.4 (+134.8%); Zipsor: 6.2 (+0.5%).
    • Net Loss: (11.8) (-282.6%); Loss Per Share: (0.20) (-281.8%); Quick Assets: 174.5 (-69.2%).
    • 2015 Guidance: Product Sales: $336M - 348M from $320M - 340M; Non-GAAP EBITDA: $108M - 116M from $95M - 110M; Non-GAAP Net Income: $58M - 66M from $40M - 50M.
    • Shares are up 5% after hours on increased volume.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:35 PM | 1 Comment
  • LF

    LeapFrog -23.6% after FQ2 miss; job cuts launched, cash balance at $52.6M

    • "Our sales were impacted by a far tougher retail landscape around the world than last year, with many of our key retail partners managing their inventories very tightly, resulting in more conservative and later placement of their up-front holiday orders," says LeapFrog (NYSE:LF) CEO John Barbour. "These challenges were compounded by reduced retail space support for our line and tough prior year comparisons from large shipments of clearance tablets and LeapBand last year. Our revenues were also reduced by significant markdown allowances to support our promotion plans for LeapTV over the holidays and our strategic move to tiered pricing on cartridge content."
    • He adds international sales continue to be hurt by Target's Canadian exit, inventory issues at an overseas distributor, and a strong dollar. Losses grew due to lower sales, markdown allowances, LeapTV inventory charges, and ERP implementation and litigation expenses.
    • In response to its struggles, the company laid off 150 employees (26% of its workforce) in October. The board and management are said to be exploring "all financial, strategic and structural alternatives available to the Company."
    • LeapFrog ended FQ2 with $52.6M in cash, down from $88.2M at the end of FQ1. U.S. sales fell 41% Y/Y, and international sales 39%. Ahead of the job cuts, GAAP operating expenses were nearly flat Y/Y at $410.3M.
    • Shares have plunged to $0.68 after hours.
    • LeapFrog's FQ2 miss, PR
     
     
     
     
    | 4:31 PM | 4 Comments
  • WWD

    Woodward beats by $0.02, beats on revenue

    • Woodward (NASDAQ:WWD): FQ4 EPS of $0.77 beats by $0.02.
    • Revenue of $562.6M (-0.5% Y/Y) beats by $22.12M.
    • Shares +2%.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:25 PM
  • LGF.A

    Lions Gate -6.3% as bad timings set Q3 misses

    • Lions Gate Entertainment (LGF -2.8%) has taken a post-market tumble, down 6.3%, as fiscal Q2 results disappointed across the board, with no help from some light timing on entertainment releases.
    • The studio swung to a net loss on both a GAAP and adjusted basis (losses of $42.1M and $28.4M respectively). Adjusted net loss per share was $0.19, vs. an expected loss of $0.01.
    • Revenues of $476.8M were down 13.8% Y/Y and missed expectations for $484.7M. Adjusted EBITDA was -$8.1M vs. $32.3M expected.
    • Episodic TV timing played a part in results, as well as shifting the wide release of film Sicario into October, which moved marketing costs earlier without the box-office benefit. The studio also took a write-down of $7.2M on The Last Witch Hunter (also not yet released during Q3), and American Ultra tanked with just over $15M in total worldwide grosses.
    • Revenue by segment: Motion Pictures, $354M (down 11.1%); Television production, $122.8M (down 20.7%).
    • It's expecting fiscal second-half slates to be driven by Orange is the New Black, Nashville, and key films The Hunger Games: Mockingjay Part 2 and Divergent series film Allegiant.
    • Conference call to come tomorrow at 9 a.m. ET.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:23 PM | 3 Comments
  • NVLN

    Aegerion Q3 top line up 54%; JUXTAPID sales up 35%; guidance raised; shares up 12% after hours

    • Aegerion Pharmaceuticals (AEGR) Q3 results ($M): Total Revenues: 67.3 (+54.0%); JUXTAPID sales: 58.8 (+34.6%); MYALEPT sales: 8.5 (+19.7%).
    • Net Loss: (9.8) (-66.3%); Loss Per Share: (0.34) (-70.0%); Quick Assets: 71.7 (-80.9%).
    • 2015 Guidance: Total Revenues: $230M - 245M from $205M - 235M; JUXTAPID Sales: $205M - 215M from $195M - 215M; MYALEPT Sales: $25M - 30M from $10M - 20M; Non-GAAP Operating Expenses: $195M - 205M; CF Ops: positive.
    • Due to the breach of certain covenants under a loan agreement with Silicon Valley Bank (SVB), the company is in default on its $25M term loan. SVB has granted a temporary forbearance on the loan and the company has reclassified $25.5M of its cash as restricted cash as a result of the default.
    • Shares are up 12% after hours on increased volume.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:21 PM
  • NVLN

    Aegerion Pharmaceuticals beats by $0.08, beats on revenue

    • Aegerion Pharmaceuticals (AEGR): Q3 EPS of -$0.34 beats by $0.08.
    • Revenue of $67.3M (+54.1% Y/Y) beats by $7.71M.
    • Shares +8.2%.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:21 PM
  • ASRT

    Depomed beats by $0.14, beats on revenue

    • Depomed (DEPO): Q3 EPS of $0.33 beats by $0.14.
    • Revenue of $105M (+104.0% Y/Y) beats by $3.36M.
    • Shares +6.4%.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:13 PM
  • NVLN

    Aegerion down 20% as investors expect bad news in today's Q3 earnings call

    • Aegerion Pharmaceuticals (AEGR -19.7%) slumps on a 4x surge in volume as investors take a decidedly bearish stance before today's Q3 earnings call at 5:00 pm ET. The company canceled its original date of November 5 for undisclosed reasons.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:01 PM
  • KMI

    Kinder Morgan to create JV for Mexican gas marketing company

    • Kinder Morgan (KMI -1.9%) says it will team up with a subsidiary of commodities logistics and trading company TrailStone Group to form a Mexican natural gas marketing company.
    • KMI says the new company will take advantage of the low cost of U.S. natural gas and new open access regulations in Mexico, which will become effective in 2016.
    • KMI also will expand its existing Mier-Monterrey pipeline system to provide up to 200M cf/day of incremental capacity into the Monterrey area, and says a further expansion could increase the total by 500M cf/day if demand exists; expansion could be completed by Q4 2017.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:58 PM | 21 Comments
  • EVEP-OLD

    EV Energy says distributable cash flow not sufficient to maintain distribution

    • EV Energy Partners (EVEP-OLD -26.1%) sinks by more than 25% after reporting a 54% Y/Y drop in Q3 revenue, falling gar short of expectations, and warning distributable cash flow likely will fall below levels needed to maintain its $0.50/share quarterly distribution.
    • "Over the next several months, as the budgeting process for 2016 is completed, EVEP will address its future quarterly distribution levels and policies to align future distributions with projected distributable cash flow," the company says.
    • Q3 production was 9.7 Bcf of natural gas, 212 Mbbl of oil and 526 Mbbl of natural gas liquids, or ~153M cfe/day, a 13% Y/Y decrease and 6% lower Q/Q.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:48 PM | 12 Comments
  • TELNY

    Telenor cuts ties to ex-CEO amid VimpelCom probe

    • Telenor (OTCPK:TELNY -0.9%) has terminated a consulting arrangement it had with former CEO Jon Fredrik Baksaas, in more fallout from the Norwegian carrier's holdings in VimpelCom (VIP -5.7%), currently under investigation over corruption in Uzbekistan.
    • Baksaas was formerly a board member at VimpelCom. Telenor has been pursuing divestiture of a one-third stake in VimpelCom, and hired a law firm to sort out its ties to the affair. VimpelCom's under investigation in the Netherlands and the U.S. over possible improper payments related to spectrum acquisition in the Uzbek market.
    • The termination with Baksaas was a mutual agreement and Baksaas will refrain from a bonus payment for 2015, Telenor said.
    • Previously: Former VimpelCom CEO Lunder in custody amid Uzbek corruption probe (Nov. 05 2015)

  • AGIO

    Phase 1 data on AG-120 fails to excite investors, Agios Pharma down 12%

    • Agios Pharmaceuticals (AGIO -11.6%) slumps on double normal volume in apparent response to its announcement of Phase 1 data on AG-120, under development for the treatment of a range of cancers. The data were presented at the AACR-NCI-EORTC International Conference on Molecular Targets and Cancer Therapeutics in Boston, MA.
    • The ongoing early-stage study is assessing AG-120 in advanced solid tumors, including glioma (brain tumor), intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma (IHCC) (liver tumor) and chondrosarcomas (sarcomas affecting the bones and joints). As of the data cut-off (September 3), 62 patients had been treated with AG-120 as monotherapy and 25 remain on treatment. Over half had high-grade tumors and received a median of three prior lines of therapy (ranging from one to six).
    • Results from 55 response-evaluable patients showed treatment with AG-120 reduced the tumor metabolite 2HG in plasma and tumor tissue. Seven of 11 IDH1+ chondrosarcoma patients had stable disease, five for at least six months. One IDH1+ IHCC patient experienced a partial response while 11 had stable disease, five for at least six months. The partial responder also showed the effect for at least six months. 10 of 20 IDH1+ glioma patients showed stable disease, four for at least six months.
    • The company is currently enrolling four expansion cohorts of 25 patients each in the three cancer types above and other IDH1+ solid tumors.
    • AG-120 is an inhibitor of the mutated form of the metabolic enzyme IDH1 (isocitrate dehydrogenase 1) which is present in a wide range of cancers.
    • Previously: Agios Pharma's AG-120 shows encouraging results in blood cancer (June 12)

  • CALA

    Calithera Bio's CB-839 halts progression of kidney cancer in 60% of patients with one partial response; shares down 20%

    • Thinly traded micro cap Calithera Biosciences (CALA -20.1%) slumps on triple normal volume, albeit on turnover of only 900K shares, in apparent response to its announcement of new clinical data from solid tumor expansion cohorts of an open-label Phase 1 study of its lead cancer product candidate, CB-839. Investors appear to have expected better results.
    • The data showed treatment with CB-839 produced stable disease across a range of tumor types as  well as one partial response in a patient with renal cell carcinoma (RCC) who experienced a 32% reduction in target lesions and generalized shrinkage of lymph node metastases. Of 15 evaluable RCC patients, nine (60%) had stable disease lasting at lease three cycles (63 days) with four patients remaining on study. In efficacy-evaluable patients across a range of cancers treated on the twice-daily regimen with food, 22 of 50 (44%) experienced stable disease or better, with five showing no progression for over eight months.
    • A maximum tolerated dose has not  been established. The majority of treatment-emergent adverse events were mild-to-moderate and reversible. In the BID cohort with food, 4.5% (n=3/66) experienced a Grade 3/4 adverse event thought to be related to CB-839 and 3% (n=2/66) discontinued due to the confirmed effects of CB-839. The stress on the liver, measured by Grade 3 elevations in the enzyme ALT, was 1.5% (n=1/66) in the BID with food cohort versus 16% (n=5/32) in the TID (three doses/day) with food group.
    • CB-839 is an inhibitor of an enzyme called glutaminase. Restricting the action of the enzyme reduces the amount of glutamine which leads to a reduction in tumor cell growth or induces tumor cell death in certain types of cancers.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:07 PM | 3 Comments

    • KBW rings the register on its Underperform call, upgrading to Market Perform, with price target boosted to $14 from $10.
    • The stock's higher today by 5.1% to $11.13.

  • BTU

    Peabody Energy agrees with NY AG to greater disclosure of financial risks

    • Peabody Energy (BTU +4.1%) reaches an agreement with the New York attorney general to more fully disclose to investors the financial risks it faces from regulations related to climate change and other environmental issues.
    • BTU’s concessions are in response to a two-year investigation by the AG that found the coal company had not been forthright with investors and regulators about threats to its business that were projected in private; the agreement does not include a monetary settlement.
    • The AG's office also is probing Exxon Mobil to determine whether the company lied to investors and the public about the effect of climate change on its profits (I, II).

  • AMRN

    CHD patients treated with statins and the active ingredient in Amarin's Vascepa showed significant improvements in coronary plaque regression; shares up 7%

    • A study of ~200 adult Japanese coronary heart disease (CHD) patients , called CHERRY, evaluating the efficacy of statin therapy [Livalo (pitavastatin)] alone and statin therapy in combination with highly-purified EPA showed that the addition of EPA significantly improved coronary plaque volume compared to treatment with statin alone. The data were presented yesterday at the American Heart Association Scientific Sessions in Orlando, Florida.
    • After six to eight months, the EPA/statin cohort (n=97) showed statistically significant improvements in coronary plaque volume (p<0.001), lipid volume (p<0.05) and fibrous volume (p<0.05) while the statin-only cohort (n=96) failed to achieve statistical significance on any measure. The prevalence of clinically significant plaque regression, defined as more than a 15% reduction in plaque volume, was significantly greater in the EPA group versus the statin-only group (48% versus 25%; p<0.001).
    • CHERRY is the first study to use IB-IVUS (integrated backscatter intravascular ultrasound) to measure the effects of statin plus EPA on plaque regression. It is considered a feasible means to predict future cardiovascular events while the analysis of specific tissue components is considered useful for assessing the risk of a coronary event in patients with atherosclerosis. The study was performed independently by researchers in Japan.
    • EPA is the active ingredient in Amarin's (AMRN +6.9%) Vascepa (icosapent ethyl), which is currently being investigated for its potential to reduce the incidence of first major cardiovascular events in high-risk patients in an ~8,000-subject study called REDUCE-IT. The company expects to complete the trial in 2017 and publish results in 2018. Over 7,700 patients have been enrolled to date.

    More on WhiteWave Foods' Q3

    • WhiteWave Foods (WWAV +4.1%) reports organic sales rose 11% in Q3.
    • Segment sales: Americas Foods & Beverages: $722.52M (+23%); Americas Fresh Foods: $147.30M (+4%); Europe Foods & Beverages: $134.81M (+4%).
    • Adjusted gross margin rate grew 110 bps to 35.3%.
    • Adjusted operating margin rate improved 70 bps to 10.2%.

  • LIND

    Lindblad Expeditions launches buyback

    • "We have significant available liquidity beyond the planned investment in the expansion of our fleet," says Lindblad Expeditions (LIND +2.1%) COO and CFO Ian Rogers, as the company - alongside its Q3 results - announces a $20M share/warrant repurchase program.
    • Q3 tour revenue of $58.6M up 13.8% Y/Y. Adjusted EBITDA of $15.8M up 16.2%. Company says its on track to meet its full-year 2015 guidance, and sees early indicators of a strong booking pace for 2016 - 63% of ticket revenue for 2016 booked as of Oct.15 vs. 61% a year ago.
    • Lindblad has an LOI for two new ships to be built, with expected deliveries in Q2 of 2017 and 2018.
    • John McLain will join as new CFO, effective tomorrow, allowing Ian Rogers to focus on COO duties.
    • SA author and Lindblad bull Dane Capital Management notes Lindblad has had a nice run higher since bottoming out in late August, but competitors RCL and NCLH have had even bigger moves. The two larger companies trade at 15x enterprise value/EBITDA vs. LIND at 10x.
    • LIND's balance sheet affords not just the buyback and two new ships, but also the opportunity for bolt-on acquisitions, says Dane. It's an inexpensive growth story, currently ignored, but maybe about to change as sell-side coverage could soon begin.
